nodes.bodyText: The additional condition is redundant. For PARTIAL, the allowed range for literal here is well within source type range. Instead, please add a comment.
The additional condition is redundant. For PARTIAL, the allowed range for literal here is well within source type range. Instead, please add a comment.
Please add a type check to the if-conditions instead of try-catch.
Flipping conjuncts would improve readability.

No need to give up here. Most of the cases could be handled:

a comparison with NaN
a comparison with any Double outside of Bigint range (including infinity)

Ok, yes. I think they can be handled too :

for NaN, should we just remove the check? currently I think there is no optimization for NaN - we could add some check to detect NaN and return false predicate.
if the double value is outside the bigint range, then probably we can do a true/false predicate depending on the operator. are you referring to that?

if the double value is outside the bigint range, then probably we can do a true/false predicate depending on the operator. are you referring to that?

yes, but mind the null. There's helper methods for that falseIfNotNull(), trueIfNotNull().

we could add some check to detect NaN and return false predicate.

That depends on the comparison operator, too. For NOT_EQUAL and for IS_DISTINCT_FROM  it will be true. And mind the null.

yes, but mind the null. There's helper methods for that falseIfNotNull(), trueIfNotNull().

Ok, yes. Ideally, we can also let the optimizations done for boundary (or out of bound) values done in the rule. I think they can handle the case where double value >= 2^63 and <= -2^63. I will test that.

That depends on the comparison operator, too. For NOT_EQUAL and for IS_DISTINCT_FROM it will be true. And mind the null.

Yes, that's true.

Ok, yes. Ideally, we can also let the optimizations done for boundary (or out of bound) values done in the rule. I think they can handle the case where double value >= 2^63 and <= -2^63. I will test that.

Exactly. That I meant by "a comparison with any Double outside of Bigint range (including infinity)".
After this is done, the only uncovered areas will be those for the Double value ranging from (+/-) 2^35 until 2^63. Please add tests for all boundary values.
I think it can be assumed here that right is a Double (because of how expressionOptimizer works).
I think it can be assumed here that right is a Long (because of how expressionOptimizer works).
float rightReal = intBitsToFloat(toIntExact((Long) right))

This case handles infinity. You could mention it in a comment.
Regarding special values, NaN is not handled still. It should fail at literalInSourceType = coerce(right, targetToSource); (line 315)

This comment looks like a general rule for partial injective types, but it's not.
Now, that the out-of-bound cases are supported, it is not obvious that the condition is false. Actually, it is false because such cases would be handled / excluded until this point.
(see the comment on code structure)

nodes.bodyText:
Instead of adding a boolean, I would restructure the code so that there are different methods for different unwrapping routines. It would be easier to follow the flow:
FULL --> out-of-bound unwrapping --> in-bound unwrapping --> give up
PARTIAL --> analyse rightValue --> either out-of-bound unwrapping or in-bound unwrapping or NaN or give up
Cast value to primitive long and use toIntExact() instead of intValue().
done
BIGINT ?

nodes.bodyText:
Yes, it should be BIGINT - but the test still passes. I checked and have a couple of findings :

both the literals BIGINT 1 (after the unwrap) and SMALLINT 1 are converted to GenericLiterals when being converted to expression. bigints are converted to generic literals when the value is in integer range, and the integers are rep as LongLiterals. I'm not sure about the reason behind not keeping integers as generic and bigints as longLiterals. could be due to some optimization or the timeline of the datatypes.
when comparing two generic literals, ExpressionVerifier doesn't check their types. It just checks whether the values are same or not. Hence, the tests pass. I'm not sure whether this is intentional.

nodes.bodyText: Can you explain why we return true in these cases?

For cases where the double literal is greater (or less) than any possible bigint value when casted to a double, we can treat it as a beyond/below type boundary check for bigint type - example if the expression is like bigint_col < cast(2^100 as double), then we can unwrap that case.
The NaN case is sent true because it gets unwrapped later as a part of NaN unwrap opt. done recently.
